segment.source: System builder deployment of Windows 10 for desktop editions
segment.target: System builder deployment of Windows 10 for desktop editions

segment.source: Get step-by-step guidance for system builders to deploy Windows 10 to desktop computers, laptops, and 2-in-1s.
segment.target: Get step-by-step guidance for system builders to deploy Windows 10 to desktop computers, laptops, and 2-in-1s.

segment.source: System builder deployment of Windows 10 for desktop editions
segment.target: System builder deployment of Windows 10 for desktop editions

segment.source: You can use this guide to deploy Windows 10 to a line of computers.
segment.target: You can use this guide to deploy Windows 10 to a line of computers.

segment.source: It provides prescriptive guidance for Windows 10 deployment, including online and offline customizations, and optional steps for specific scenarios.
segment.target: It provides prescriptive guidance for Windows 10 deployment, including online and offline customizations, and optional steps for specific scenarios.

segment.source: It is intended to help system builders (level 200 technicians) with both 64-bit and 32-bit configurations, and applies to Windows 10 for desktop editions (Home, Pro, Enterprise, and Education).
segment.target: It is intended to help system builders (level 200 technicians) with both 64-bit and 32-bit configurations, and applies to Windows 10 for desktop editions (Home, Pro, Enterprise, and Education).

segment.source: Prepare your lab environment
segment.target: Prepare your lab environment

segment.source: The first step is to set up your lab environment, which includes installing the latest Windows Assessment and Deployment Kit (Windows ADK) tools onto your designated Technician computer.
segment.target: The first step is to set up your lab environment, which includes installing the latest Windows Assessment and Deployment Kit (Windows ADK) tools onto your designated Technician computer.

segment.source: The Technician computer must run Windows 10 x64 if you are going to deploy x64 images, or run Windows 10 x86 for x86 image deployment.
segment.target: The Technician computer must run Windows 10 x64 if you are going to deploy x64 images, or run Windows 10 x86 for x86 image deployment.

segment.source: Incorrect configurations may result in supported architecture mismatch while using deployment tools in the Windows ADK.
segment.target: Incorrect configurations may result in supported architecture mismatch while using deployment tools in the Windows ADK.

segment.source: Where noted, follow the appropriate guidelines for either a 64-bit vs 32-bit deployment.
segment.target: Where noted, follow the appropriate guidelines for either a 64-bit vs 32-bit deployment.

segment.source: Before starting the deployment procedure, you need to download the kits that will be used throughout the guide.
segment.target: Before starting the deployment procedure, you need to download the kits that will be used throughout the guide.

segment.source: Go to the OEM Partner CenterDownloads and InstallationUnderstanding ADKs and OPKs.
segment.target: Go to the OEM Partner CenterDownloads and InstallationUnderstanding ADKs and OPKs.

segment.source: For a list of resources and kits that will be used and where to obtain them, see What you will need and where to get it.
segment.target: For a list of resources and kits that will be used and where to obtain them, see What you will need and where to get it.

segment.source: You will need two USB drives.
segment.target: You will need two USB drives.

segment.source: USB-A will be used to boot the system in Windows Preinstallation Environment (WinPE).
segment.target: USB-A will be used to boot the system in Windows Preinstallation Environment (WinPE).

segment.source: USB-B will be used to move files between computers, store deployment and recovery scripts, and store and apply created images.
segment.target: USB-B will be used to move files between computers, store deployment and recovery scripts, and store and apply created images.

segment.source: Install Windows with basic customizations
segment.target: Install Windows with basic customizations

segment.source: Please obtain Windows 10 x86/x64 DVD media from a Microsoft Authorized Distributor.
segment.target: Please obtain Windows 10 x86/x64 DVD media from a Microsoft Authorized Distributor.

segment.source: For a document to help you tailor the customizations defined in your unattend.xml file, see the Windows Guidelines for System Builders and Windows Policy for System Builders.
segment.target: For a document to help you tailor the customizations defined in your unattend.xml file, see the Windows Guidelines for System Builders and Windows Policy for System Builders.

segment.source: Copy the sourcesInstall.wim file from the directory in the Windows 10 media that you will be deploying to your local Desktop (~3gb).
segment.target: Copy the sourcesInstall.wim file from the directory in the Windows 10 media that you will be deploying to your local Desktop (~3gb).

segment.source: Copy WIM
segment.target: Copy WIM

segment.source: Run Windows System Image Manager to start creating an answer file from scratch.
segment.target: Run Windows System Image Manager to start creating an answer file from scratch.

segment.source: This tool allows you to create or manage your answer files in an easy and organized manner.
segment.target: This tool allows you to create or manage your answer files in an easy and organized manner.

segment.source: Run SIM
segment.target: Run SIM

segment.source: Navigate to FileSelect Windows Image.
segment.target: Navigate to FileSelect Windows Image.

segment.source: Browse to your local desktop and select Install.wim.
segment.target: Browse to your local desktop and select Install.wim.

segment.source: Catalog file will be created (.clg file) for that specified wim.
segment.target: Catalog file will be created (.clg file) for that specified wim.

segment.target: Please make sure install.wim has read/write permissions.

segment.target: If you continue getting error, make sure correct architecture (x86 or x64) Windows 10 is installed on technician computer.

segment.target: If you are creating catalog for x64 Windows 10 image, you are required to use x64 Windows 10 installed on x64 Windows 10 computer.

segment.target: Install.wim image and Windows 10 ADK versions must be the same.

segment.target: Click OK to associate the answer file with the Windows Image.

segment.target: To add a driver to Windows PE, click Insert select Driver Path and select pass 1 windowsPE and then browse to the driver.

segment.target: Please see and use the Windows 10 default product key from OEM Partner Center listed under Default product keys tab.

segment.source: Add a product key that matches the Windows edition.
segment.target: Add a product key that matches the Windows edition.

segment.source: This key isn't used to activate Windows, so you can reuse the same key for multiple installations:
segment.target: This key isn't used to activate Windows, so you can reuse the same key for multiple installations:

segment.source: In the Answer File pane, select Components\1 windowsPE\amd64_Microsoft-Windows-Setup_neutral\UserData\ProductKey.
segment.target: In the Answer File pane, select Components\1 windowsPE\amd64_Microsoft-Windows-Setup_neutral\UserData\ProductKey.

segment.source: In the ProductKey Properties pane, under Settings, enter the value next to Key.
segment.target: In the ProductKey Properties pane, under Settings, enter the value next to Key.

segment.source: Important: These product keys cannot be used for activation.
segment.target: Important: These product keys cannot be used for activation.

segment.source: You will need to type a software product key during the installation process for activation.
segment.target: You will need to type a software product key during the installation process for activation.

segment.source: These keys will be removed when sysprep generalize is run.
segment.target: These keys will be removed when sysprep generalize is run.

segment.source: The end user will be required to type the unique product key from the Certificate of Authenticity (COA) label when first booting Windows 10.
segment.target: The end user will be required to type the unique product key from the Certificate of Authenticity (COA) label when first booting Windows 10.

segment.source: Add your support information:
segment.target: Add your support information:

segment.source: In the Answer File pane, select Components\4 specialize\amd64_Microsoft-Windows-Shell-Setup_neutral\OEMInformation.
segment.target: In the Answer File pane, select Components\4 specialize\amd64_Microsoft-Windows-Shell-Setup_neutral\OEMInformation.

segment.source: In the OEMInformation Properties pane, in the Settings section, update the following values: company name (Manufacturer), hours (SupportHours), phone number (SupportPhone), and website (SupportURL).
segment.target: In the OEMInformation Properties pane, in the Settings section, update the following values: company name (Manufacturer), hours (SupportHours), phone number (SupportPhone), and website (SupportURL).

segment.source: Prepare your computer to boot to audit mode after the Windows installation is complete:
segment.target: Prepare your computer to boot to audit mode after the Windows installation is complete:

segment.source: In the Windows Image pane, expand Components, right-click amd64_Microsoft-Windows-Deployment, and then select Add Setting to Pass 7 oobeSystem.
segment.target: In the Windows Image pane, expand Components, right-click amd64_Microsoft-Windows-Deployment, and then select Add Setting to Pass 7 oobeSystem.

segment.source: In the Answer File pane, select Components\7 oobeSystem\amd64_Microsoft-Windows-Deployment _neutral\Reseal.
segment.target: In the Answer File pane, select Components\7 oobeSystem\amd64_Microsoft-Windows-Deployment _neutral\Reseal.

segment.source: In the Reseal Properties pane, in the Settings section, add the following value: Mode =Audit.
segment.target: In the Reseal Properties pane, in the Settings section, add the following value: Mode =Audit.

segment.source: Set the Internet Explorer home page:
segment.target: Set the Internet Explorer home page:

segment.source: In the Windows Image pane, right-click amd64_Microsoft-Windows-IE-InternetExplorer, and then select Add Setting to Pass 4 specialize.
segment.target: In the Windows Image pane, right-click amd64_Microsoft-Windows-IE-InternetExplorer, and then select Add Setting to Pass 4 specialize.

segment.source: In the Answer File pane, select Components\4 specialize\amd64_Microsoft-Windows-Microsoft-Windows-IE-InternetExplorer_neutral.
segment.target: In the Answer File pane, select Components\4 specialize\amd64_Microsoft-Windows-Microsoft-Windows-IE-InternetExplorer_neutral.

segment.source: In the IE-InternetExplorer Properties pane, in the Settings section, select Home_page, and add the URL of your website.
segment.target: In the IE-InternetExplorer Properties pane, in the Settings section, select Home_page, and add the URL of your website.

segment.target: Important: Connecting the computer to internet is not recommended during manufacturing stages.

segment.target: It is not recommended to get the updates from Windows Update in audit mode.

segment.target: Troubleshoot: If booting with USB fails, please make sure you have prioritized USB boot instead of HDD boot.

segment.target: To do so, open the BIOS menu and adjust the boot sequence so that the first option is USB boot.

segment.target: In order to capture a generalized and stable image, none of the Windows passes must be completed.

segment.target: To generalize the image again, press CTRL+SHIFT+F3 to skip OOBE and boot in Audit mode.

segment.source: If you use an x64 Windows 10 image, add x64 drivers; if you use an x86 Windows 10 image, add x86 drivers.
segment.target: If you use an x64 Windows 10 image, add x64 drivers; if you use an x86 Windows 10 image, add x86 drivers.

segment.source: Adding driver packages one by one.
segment.target: Adding driver packages one by one.

segment.source: (.inf files) SampleDriver\driver.inf is a sample driver package that is specific to the computer model.
segment.target: (.inf files) SampleDriver\driver.inf is a sample driver package that is specific to the computer model.

segment.source: Type your own specific driver path.
segment.target: Type your own specific driver path.

segment.source: If you have multiple driver packages, skip to the next step.
segment.target: If you have multiple driver packages, skip to the next step.

segment.source: Multiple drivers can be added on one command line if you specify a folder instead of an .inf file.
segment.target: Multiple drivers can be added on one command line if you specify a folder instead of an .inf file.

segment.source: To install all of the drivers in a folder and all its subfolders, use the /recurse option.
segment.target: To install all of the drivers in a folder and all its subfolders, use the /recurse option.

segment.source: Review the contents of the %WINDIR%\Inf\ (C:\mount\windows\Windows\Inf directory in the mounted Windows image to ensure that the .inf files were installed.
segment.target: Review the contents of the %WINDIR%\Inf\ (C:\mount\windows\Windows\Inf directory in the mounted Windows image to ensure that the .inf files were installed.

segment.source: Drivers added to the Windows image are named Oem.inf.
segment.target: Drivers added to the Windows image are named Oem.inf.

segment.source: This is to ensure unique naming for new drivers added to the computer.
segment.target: This is to ensure unique naming for new drivers added to the computer.

segment.source: For example, the files MyDriver1.inf and MyDriver2.inf are renamed Oem0.inf and Oem1.inf.
segment.target: For example, the files MyDriver1.inf and MyDriver2.inf are renamed Oem0.inf and Oem1.inf.

segment.source: Verify your driver has been installed for both images.
segment.target: Verify your driver has been installed for both images.

segment.source: Important: If the driver contains only the installer package and doesn’t have an .inf file, you may choose to install the driver in AUDIT mode by double-clicking the corresponding installer package.
segment.target: Important: If the driver contains only the installer package and doesn’t have an .inf file, you may choose to install the driver in AUDIT mode by double-clicking the corresponding installer package.

segment.source: Some drivers may be incompatible with Sysprep tool; they will be removed after sysprep generalize even if they have been injected offline.
segment.target: Some drivers may be incompatible with Sysprep tool; they will be removed after sysprep generalize even if they have been injected offline.

segment.source: In this case, you need to add an extra parameter to USB-B\AnswerFiles\UnattendSysprep.xml in order to persist the drivers in the image when the image will be generalized.
segment.target: In this case, you need to add an extra parameter to USB-B\AnswerFiles\UnattendSysprep.xml in order to persist the drivers in the image when the image will be generalized.

segment.source: PersistAllDeviceInstallstrue/PersistAllDeviceInstalls
segment.target: PersistAllDeviceInstallstrue/PersistAllDeviceInstalls

segment.source: This property must be added to USB-B\AnswerFiles\UnattendSysprep.xml during generalize pass in order to persist the drivers in the image.
segment.target: This property must be added to USB-B\AnswerFiles\UnattendSysprep.xml during generalize pass in order to persist the drivers in the image.

segment.source: For more information about the details of this property and how to add it to an answer file, see PersistAllDeviceInstalls.
segment.target: For more information about the details of this property and how to add it to an answer file, see PersistAllDeviceInstalls.

segment.source: Modify Start layout
segment.target: Modify Start layout

segment.source: The Start tile layout in Windows 10 provides OEMs the ability to append tiles to the default Start layout to include Web links, secondary tiles, classic Windows applications, and universal Windows apps.
segment.target: The Start tile layout in Windows 10 provides OEMs the ability to append tiles to the default Start layout to include Web links, secondary tiles, classic Windows applications, and universal Windows apps.

segment.source: OEMs can use this layout to make it applicable to multiple regions or markets without duplicating a lot of the work.
segment.target: OEMs can use this layout to make it applicable to multiple regions or markets without duplicating a lot of the work.

segment.source: In addition, OEMs can add up to three default apps to the frequently used apps section in the system area, which delivers sytem-driven lists o the user including important or frequently accessed system locations and recently installed apps.
segment.target: In addition, OEMs can add up to three default apps to the frequently used apps section in the system area, which delivers sytem-driven lists o the user including important or frequently accessed system locations and recently installed apps.

segment.source: Create Layoutmodification.xml.
segment.target: Create Layoutmodification.xml.

segment.source: Note: It is recommended to start with the sample on USB-B\StartLayout\layoutModification.xml as it conforms to the samples in this guide (Example Only).
segment.target: Note: It is recommended to start with the sample on USB-B\StartLayout\layoutModification.xml as it conforms to the samples in this guide (Example Only).

segment.source: The Sample LayoutModification.xml shows two groups called “Fabrikam Group 1” and “Fabrikam Group 2”, which contain tiles that will be applied if the device country/region matches what’s specified in Region (in this case, the regions are Germany and United States).
segment.target: The Sample LayoutModification.xml shows two groups called “Fabrikam Group 1” and “Fabrikam Group 2”, which contain tiles that will be applied if the device country/region matches what’s specified in Region (in this case, the regions are Germany and United States).

segment.source: Each group contains three tiles and the various elements you need to use depending on the tile that you want to pin to Start.
segment.target: Each group contains three tiles and the various elements you need to use depending on the tile that you want to pin to Start.

segment.source: Keep the following in mind when creating your LayoutModification.xml file:
segment.target: Keep the following in mind when creating your LayoutModification.xml file:

segment.source: If you are pinning a Classic Windows application using the start:DesktopApplicationTile tag and you don’t know the application’s application user model ID, you need to create a .lnk file in a legacy Start Menu directory before first boot.
segment.target: If you are pinning a Classic Windows application using the start:DesktopApplicationTile tag and you don’t know the application’s application user model ID, you need to create a .lnk file in a legacy Start Menu directory before first boot.

segment.source: If you use the start:DesktopApplicationTile tag to pin a legacy .url shortcut to Start, you must create a .url file and add this file to a legacy Start Menu directory before first boot.
segment.target: If you use the start:DesktopApplicationTile tag to pin a legacy .url shortcut to Start, you must create a .url file and add this file to a legacy Start Menu directory before first boot.

segment.source: For the above scenarios, you can use the following directories to put the .url or .lnk files:
segment.target: For the above scenarios, you can use the following directories to put the .url or .lnk files:

segment.source: %APPDATA%\Microsoft\Windows\Start Menu\Programs\
segment.target: %APPDATA%\Microsoft\Windows\Start Menu\Programs\

segment.source: %ALLUSERSPROFILE%\Microsoft\Windows\Start Menu\Programs\
segment.target: %ALLUSERSPROFILE%\Microsoft\Windows\Start Menu\Programs\

segment.source: Save the LayoutModification.xml file.
segment.target: Save the LayoutModification.xml file.

segment.source: Add your LayoutModification.xml file to the Windows image.
segment.target: Add your LayoutModification.xml file to the Windows image.

segment.source: You’ll need to put the file in the following specific location before first boot.
segment.target: You’ll need to put the file in the following specific location before first boot.

segment.source: If the file exists, you should replace the LayoutModification.XML that is already included in the image.
segment.target: If the file exists, you should replace the LayoutModification.XML that is already included in the image.

segment.target: Where E: is the drive letter of USB-B.

segment.target: If you pinned tiles that require .url or .lnk files, add the files to the following legacy Start Menu directories:

segment.target: Note: If you don’t create a LayoutModification.xml file and you continue to use the Start Unattend settings, the OS will use the Unattend answer file and take the first 12 SquareTiles or DesktoporSquareTiles settings specified in the Unattend file.

segment.source: The system then places these tiles automatically within the newly-created groups at the end of Start.
segment.target: The system then places these tiles automatically within the newly-created groups at the end of Start.

segment.source: The first six tiles are placed in the first OEM group, and the second set of six tiles are placed in the second OEM group.
segment.target: The first six tiles are placed in the first OEM group, and the second set of six tiles are placed in the second OEM group.

segment.source: Configure the Setup experience for the user
segment.target: Configure the Setup experience for the user

segment.source: After you install Office on the device, you also need to configure the Setup experience for the user.
segment.target: After you install Office on the device, you also need to configure the Setup experience for the user.

segment.source: This is the experience the user sees when they open an Office app for the first time on the device.
segment.target: This is the experience the user sees when they open an Office app for the first time on the device.

segment.source: This also is intended to ensure that Office is properly licensed and activated.
segment.target: This also is intended to ensure that Office is properly licensed and activated.

segment.source: Setup mode
segment.target: Setup mode

segment.source: Description
segment.target: Description

segment.source: OEM
segment.target: OEM

segment.source: In this mode, a customer can choose to try, buy, or activate Office with an existing account, PIN, or product key.
segment.target: In this mode, a customer can choose to try, buy, or activate Office with an existing account, PIN, or product key.

segment.source: This mode doesn’t support Activation for Office (AFO) or AFO late binding.
segment.target: This mode doesn’t support Activation for Office (AFO) or AFO late binding.

segment.source: Therefore, if you choose this mode, you need to provide the customer with an Activation Card (formerly called a product key card or a Microsoft Product Identifier (MPI) card).
segment.target: Therefore, if you choose this mode, you need to provide the customer with an Activation Card (formerly called a product key card or a Microsoft Product Identifier (MPI) card).

segment.source: OEMTA
segment.target: OEMTA

segment.source: This mode supports the try, buy, or activate experience of the OEM mode as well as supporting AFO and AFO late binding.
segment.target: This mode supports the try, buy, or activate experience of the OEM mode as well as supporting AFO and AFO late binding.

segment.source: This mode supports Office activation through the device’s Windows product key, which means the customer wouldn’t need to enter a 5x5 product key code.
segment.target: This mode supports Office activation through the device’s Windows product key, which means the customer wouldn’t need to enter a 5x5 product key code.

segment.source: OEM Mode – Provide user with activation card
segment.target: OEM Mode – Provide user with activation card

segment.source: In command prompt go to drive letter for USB-B\Officev16
segment.target: In command prompt go to drive letter for USB-B\Officev16

segment.source: Type and run:
segment.target: Type and run:

segment.source: oemsetup.cmd Mode=OEM
segment.target: oemsetup.cmd Mode=OEM

segment.source: OEMTA Mode – Activation is done through the device’s Windows product key.
segment.target: OEMTA Mode – Activation is done through the device’s Windows product key.

segment.source: Type and run:
segment.target: Type and run:

segment.target: oemsetup.cmd Mode=OEMTA Referral=

segment.target: Download Microsoft Office Single Image v15.4 from the OEM Partner Center.

segment.source: Open an elevated command prompt.
segment.target: Open an elevated command prompt.

segment.source: Copy the content of the OPK to a directory, which will be OfficeSingleImagev15.4InstallationDirectory.
segment.target: Copy the content of the OPK to a directory, which will be OfficeSingleImagev15.4InstallationDirectory.

segment.source: Navigate to the installation directory.
segment.target: Navigate to the installation directory.

segment.source: The installation directory is the folder that contains the files shown in following figure.
segment.target: The installation directory is the folder that contains the files shown in following figure.

segment.source: Installation directory
segment.target: Installation directory

segment.source: Important: The installation process for the OPK is the same for computers that run 32-bit operating systems or 64-bit operating systems.
segment.target: Important: The installation process for the OPK is the same for computers that run 32-bit operating systems or 64-bit operating systems.

segment.source: You can preload the 32-bit version of Office 2013 on computers that run either 32-bit or 64-bit operating systems.
segment.target: You can preload the 32-bit version of Office 2013 on computers that run either 32-bit or 64-bit operating systems.

segment.source: You can preload the 64-bit version of Office 2013 only on computers that run 64-bit operating systems.
segment.target: You can preload the 64-bit version of Office 2013 only on computers that run 64-bit operating systems.

segment.source: To prevent possible compatibility issues with add-ins or third-party applications, preload only the 32-bit version of the OPK on both 32-bit and 64-bit computers.
segment.target: To prevent possible compatibility issues with add-ins or third-party applications, preload only the 32-bit version of the OPK on both 32-bit and 64-bit computers.

segment.source: Run oemsetup.en-us script.
segment.target: Run oemsetup.en-us script.

segment.target: After installation is complete, Microsoft Office Single Image v15.4 OOBE application tile will be placed on Apps view.

segment.target: To pin the to the start screen please see Section 4.2.4 Pinning Desktop Apps to Start Screen and Taskbar and type in %allusersprofile%\Microsoft\Windows\Start Menu\Programs\Microsoft Office.lnk to AppIdOrPath property.

segment.source: The walkthrough-deploy.bat in USB-B\deployment folder will partition the device based on device mode.
segment.target: The walkthrough-deploy.bat in USB-B\deployment folder will partition the device based on device mode.

segment.source: Important: The Recovery partition must be the partition after the Windows partition to ensure winre.wim can be kept up-to-date during the life of the device.
segment.target: Important: The Recovery partition must be the partition after the Windows partition to ensure winre.wim can be kept up-to-date during the life of the device.

segment.source: In Windows 10 Version 1511, we are changing our recommendation to have the WinRE partition placed after the OS partition.
segment.target: In Windows 10 Version 1511, we are changing our recommendation to have the WinRE partition placed after the OS partition.

segment.source: This allows future growth of the WinRE partition during updates.
segment.target: This allows future growth of the WinRE partition during updates.

segment.source: Today with the WinRE partition at the front of the disk, the size of it can never be changed, making it difficult to update WinRE when needed.
segment.target: Today with the WinRE partition at the front of the disk, the size of it can never be changed, making it difficult to update WinRE when needed.

segment.source: We will continue to support having the WinRE partition located in different parts of the disk, but we encouraging you to follow the new recommendation.
segment.target: We will continue to support having the WinRE partition located in different parts of the disk, but we encouraging you to follow the new recommendation.

segment.source: E:\Deployment\walkthrough-deploy.bat E:\Images\BasicImage.wim
segment.target: E:\Deployment\walkthrough-deploy.bat E:\Images\BasicImage.wim

segment.source: Note: There are several pauses in the script.
segment.target: Note: There are several pauses in the script.

segment.source: You will be prompted Y/N for the Apply operation if this is a Compact OS deployment.
segment.target: You will be prompted Y/N for the Apply operation if this is a Compact OS deployment.

segment.source: Note: Only use Compact OS on high end storage devices because Compact OS performance depends on the storage device capabilities.
segment.target: Note: Only use Compact OS on high end storage devices because Compact OS performance depends on the storage device capabilities.

segment.source: Compact OS is NOT recommend on rotational devices or storage greater than 32 GB.
segment.target: Compact OS is NOT recommend on rotational devices or storage greater than 32 GB.

segment.source: For more information, see Compact OS.
segment.target: For more information, see Compact OS.

segment.target: Remove USB-A and USB-B and type exit to reboot your computer with Windows 10.

segment.target: Upon deploying your model specific image to destination computers, boot the computer with master image for the first time in AUDIT mode

segment.source: Important: In order to minimize the first boot time, (Boot > Specialize > OOBE > Start screen) specialize pass must be completed in the factory.
segment.target: Important: In order to minimize the first boot time, (Boot > Specialize > OOBE > Start screen) specialize pass must be completed in the factory.

segment.source: Specialize pass will configure hardware specific information which Windows will run on.
segment.target: Specialize pass will configure hardware specific information which Windows will run on.

segment.source: For more information about the first boot time requirements, see Windows Policy for System Builders.
segment.target: For more information about the first boot time requirements, see Windows Policy for System Builders.

segment.source: Please note that at the end of the section Update images manually by using AUDIT MODE (online servicing), the system was sealed with OOBE mode.
segment.target: Please note that at the end of the section Update images manually by using AUDIT MODE (online servicing), the system was sealed with OOBE mode.

segment.target: Please proceed with Audit.

segment.target: If the system boots in OOBE, press CTRL+SHIFT+F3 in order to pass OOBE and boot in audit mode.

segment.target: Finally, run the Sysprep tool (C:\Windows\System32\Sysprep\sysprep.exe) and seal the system back to OOBE and Shutdown but withoutGeneralize.

segment.source: Differences between 64-bit and 32-bit deployment
segment.target: Differences between 64-bit and 32-bit deployment

segment.source: It is recommended to consider 64-bit deployment versus 32-bit deployment disk footprint according to the storage of the device you are manufacturing.
segment.target: It is recommended to consider 64-bit deployment versus 32-bit deployment disk footprint according to the storage of the device you are manufacturing.

segment.source: The overall deployment flow mentioned in this guide doesn’t differ between 64-bit and 32-bit deployment.
segment.target: The overall deployment flow mentioned in this guide doesn’t differ between 64-bit and 32-bit deployment.

segment.source: Only some of the resource versions and the way those resources are created differs.
segment.target: Only some of the resource versions and the way those resources are created differs.

segment.source: When Windows ADK gets installed on a technican computer the the deployment tools in the ADK would be installed according to the architecture of the Windows on technician computer.
segment.target: When Windows ADK gets installed on a technican computer the the deployment tools in the ADK would be installed according to the architecture of the Windows on technician computer.
